reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central move in the essay: the claim that even a “common-sense utopia” (abundance, freedom, happiness) could still fall far short of near-best value due to non-obvious moral failures, which supports the broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion. However, it attacks this mostly by a meta-level rejection (“if a theory says this, reject the theory”) rather than engaging the essay’s main structural arguments (many independent-value dimensions, population ethics/scale sensitivity, digital minds, bounded vs unbounded value, and the technical fussiness analysis). It also somewhat mischaracterizes the essay by spotlighting acausal trade as if it were a main driver, whereas it’s presented as one of many “and so on” possibilities rather than a core premise. Still, it is correct that some cited failure modes are speculative and that one could respond by discounting highly esoteric moral requirements; that’s a legitimate (though under-argued) pushback. The critique is clear, focused on a single objection, and contains little fluff.
title: Labeling human flourishing as catastrophe reveals alienated moral criteria
